sentence.text: This 3-year-old female child (III.2), the sister of Patient 1, was born at term after an uneventful pregnancy.
Her birth weight is reported as low but was not recorded.
Her motor development was delayed (she was walking at 1.5-year old).
Her physical appearance (Fig. 4) resembled that of her brother with short stature, a small short nose, midface hypoplasia, hypertelorism, high arched palate, long philtrum, and relatively small ears.
In addition, she had epicanthic folds and congenital stricture of lacrimal ducts, which was operated upon twice.
Generalized brachydactyly and bilateral clinodactyly of the little fingers were also noted.
There was no limitation of joint movements.
At the age of 3 years her height was 87.5 cm (−2 SD), weight 12 kg (−1.4 SD), and head circumference 48 cm (−1 SD) and she started complaining from joint pain.
Arm span was 78 and upper segment to lower segment ratio was 2.3.
Similarly, she had moderate sensorineural deafness and she is wearing a hearing aid.
Ophthalmologic evaluation, laboratory investigations, metabolic screening, and chromosomal examination were done for her and yielded normal results.
Skeletal radiographs (Fig. 5) demonstrated short long bones (humerus, radius, ulna, tibia, and fibula).
All had large and wide epiphyses and flared metaphyses.
The femur showed the characteristic dumbbell shape.
These features were associated with platyspondyly with coronal clefting.
Atlanto-axial and occipital bones showed no abnormalities.
